At 15:58 15/09/2004, you wrote:

>All right, here's some thoughts.  Anybody have any feedback?
>
>First, I can settle for a fixed-enlargement scale.  I didn't want to,
>but I really want a better enlargement method, even if it isn't able
>to do arbitrary scale.  Now, having fixed-position outputs, the
>problem is reduced to a classification problem.  "Should this pixel be
>above or below the center?"  Easily solved, except for the BILLIONS of
>training samples...

I can't work out what you meant by "above or below the center"?  Surely 
it's not classification, it's function fitting?  Unless it's in black and 
white?

>Second, to get an idea of how many hidden nodes I will need, I can
>evolve for the normal input nodes, but with only one output node.
>However many hidden nodes it takes for one, that's how many I start
>with for trying to evolve the final solution.

I think you need to give a brief summary of what experiment you're 
imagining now, because I cannot follow you.  Surely there's only ever one 
output node (because you run the network once for each pixel you are asking 
about...)

>Third, this is not a controller, it is a classification problem.  So,
>I can (perhaps) take some shortcuts where connectivity is concerned.
>Instead of splitting one connection and then adding more connections
>later, I can add a node that is pre-connected to all inputs and all
>outputs, but with nearly 0 weights.  Then, it only has to optimize the
>weights.  Except then I have to decide if a new node adds to the first
>hidden layer or a second (or a third).  Hmm...

Except for connections between hidden nodes?

>Any other ideas?

I need a bit more explanation, I think.  I'm glad you're still going on 
with it, however.

         Ian
